paragraphs.text: "Hello World!".zipWithIndex.map { case (x:Char,i:Int) => if (i % 2 == 0) x.toLower else x.toUpper }.mkString

val range = 1 to 1000

println
println ("min = " + range.min)
println ("max = " + range.max)
println ("sum = " + range.sum)

def reduce(agg:(Int,Int), value:Int) = (agg._1 + value, agg._2 + 1)
val zero = (0,0)

val agg = range.foldLeft(zero)(reduce)
val avg = agg._1.toFloat / agg._2.toFloat

### Use Case: Maps
Options naturally arise whenever operations might not return a valid value. For example Maps

personToAge: scala.collection.immutable.Map[String,Int] = Map(Alice -> 23, Bob -> 21)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Mutable Collections

So far we have been using immutable collections, i.e. collections where each modification would return a new collection. But sometimes we want to work with mutable collections. This is particularily useful when building new collections.

result.msg:
Mutable Collections

So far we have been using immutable collections, i.e. collections where each modification would return a new collection. But sometimes we want to work with mutable collections. This is particularily useful when building new collections.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Views

Normally transformation on collections are immediately materialized. This may be inefficient or consume lots of memory. Another approach is to use a `view` instead, where calculations are performed lazily.

result.msg:
Views

Normally transformation on collections are immediately materialized. This may be inefficient or consume lots of memory. Another approach is to use a view instead, where calculations are performed lazily.
